column4: you can use your private key instead of a password - that saves a lot of messing about with password prompts
but lots of users would be logging in
so that wouldn't work
keys won't work
so theres not like a modified version of the ssh client that lets me specifiy it in the command like user:password@host
so what's the point of the exercise?  you want to prompt for a password and pass it on to ssh?  why not just let ssh prompt for a password instead?
I am using a gui interface todo it
if you specify the password on the command line, everyone on the system can see the password when they run "ps"
thats fine with me
since no one is gonna actually be logged into the machine
if you don't mind everyone seeing the password, you may as well not use passwords.  leave all the passwords empty - then you won't need to propmt for them.
no they need to be passworded
but the actuall accounts are set to goto /bin/false or whatever
with insecure passwords?  why?
so no one is actually logged into the computer
